title.narrative: Ethiopia: Targeted country assistance
Éthiopie (l'): Aide ciblée aux pays

description.narrative:
Plans d’assistance technique ciblée aux pays L’assistance technique ciblée aux pays (TCA) est octroyée sous forme de ressources destinées aux partenaires présents dans les pays. La TCA est un élément du cadre d’engagement avec les partenaires (PEF) de Gavi. Le plan de TCA d’un pays est établie selon les besoins exprimés du dit pays lors de l’évaluation conjointe. Un plan comprend une liste d’activités, d’étapes clés, et un budget pour une année dite. L’assistance technique est un soutien non financier fourni par des spécialistes. Elle peut revêtir plusieurs formes : partage d’information et de savoir-faire, formation et services-conseils.
L’assistance technique fournie dans le cadre du PEF est appelée aide ciblée aux pays. Ce type de soutien vise principalement à payer le personnel basé en permanence dans les bureaux pays des partenaires. Il repose sur la demande et les besoins identifiés par les pays eux-mêmes.

Targeted country assistance (TCA) are resources provided to in-country partners under Gavi’s partners’ engagement framework (PEF). A country’s TCA plan is based on needs expressed by the country during the joint appraisal discussions. It includes sets of activities, milestones and budget for a given year.Technical assistance is non-financial support provided by specialists. It can take the form of sharing information and expertise, training and consulting services.
The technical assistance provided through PEF is called targeted country assistance (TCA). This type of support mainly consists of staff permanently based in partners’ country offices. It is based on the demand and needs identified by the countries themselves.

title.narrative: CDC Foundation : Vaccine-Specific Support
10 months of the measles 5 dose RCT implemented in study sites (across 60 woredas). Finalize field protocol for the endline survey.

target.value: Continue the implementation period, and carry out the endline survey for a study to examine the impact of the use of a 5 dose measles vaccine vial on measles coverage. CDC has been working with Ethiopia MoH, JSI, WHO, UNICEF, EPHI and RHBs to implement a randomized control study to document and measure the impact of reducing the measles vaccine vial size from a 10-dose vial to a 5-dose vial. The baseline is complete, and the study started implementation mid-December 2020 and will continue for 1 year. We are implementing 3 arms in the study (5-dose vial and trainings, 10-dose vial and trainings, and control group) and will measure the impact on immunization coverage pre and post implementation. The findings from this study will be highly relevant for Ethiopia and other countries considering changing to a 5-dose measles vial.

comment.narrative: 10 months of implementation are now complete and are on track for completion of the implementation period in March-April 2022. There have been some health facilities that are noted to be impacted by security issues, which have hampered implementation of the intervention, and all health services, broadly speaking. These impacts will be accounted for when analyzing the results from this study. The endline survey field protocol is currently under revision, with plan for the endline survey still in place for March-April 2022.

title.narrative: Demand creation for MCV2 and RI; data triangulation for programatic use around MCV2 and RI; recommendations for reporting/recording quality improvements

comment.narrative: An ongoing MCV2 barriers assessment is nearing completion and will provide important information that will guide the tailoring of this technical assistance around increasing MCV2 uptake in Oromia Region. The assessment had minor delays which have resulted in the minor delays with this work.

title.narrative: Carry out a dissemination workshop on the barriers to MCV2 uptake in Oromia Region (across 18 woredas); supportive supervision in priority Zones focusing on MCV2; systematically assess the defaulter tracing mechanisms in the Region broadly

comment.narrative: The dissemination workshop is delayed and we are awaiting the final report of the MCV2 barriers study findings. However, planning is underway to hold this workshop after the general election in August/September 2021. Supportive supervision to priority Zones focusing on MCV2 is ongoing as is the systematic assessment of defaulter tracing mechanisms. For the latter, a new wooden design of tickler boxes is under production to implement a more systematic system in pilot areas.

target.value: Continued technical assistance in support of increasing MCV2 uptake in Ethiopia in Oromia Region, including a) programmatic support for strategies to increase uptake; b) support for increasing the quality of recording/reporting of vaccines doses delivered in 2YL; c) assessing strategies for improving defaulter tracing and, use of MCV2 as an opportunity for catch-up of children who missed their measles vaccination during the first year of life; d) communications messaging to increase awareness and demand for MCV2; e) capacity building for data quality assurance, analysis and triangulation of MCV1 & MCV2 data, measles surveillance data and outbreak data at the district level); f) support field implementation of operations research on aforementioned topics

comment.narrative: The workshop regarding the findings is tentatively scheduled for January 2022. Supportive supervision within the priority zones continues. For the systematic assessment of defaulter tracing mechanisms, a detailed protocol has been developed by the CDCF consultant in consultation with the CDC team and the systematic assessment will be carried out in the new calendar year.

title.narrative: 6 months of the measles 5 dose RCT implemention completed in study sites (across 60 woredas). Interim report on progress at half way point of implementtaion.

target.value: Continue the implementation period, and carry out the endline survey for a study to examine the impact of the use of a 5 dose measles vaccine vial on measles coverage. CDC has been working with Ethiopia MoH, JSI, WHO, UNICEF, EPHI and RHBs to implement a randomized control study to document and measure the impact of reducing the measles vaccine vial size from a 10-dose vial to a 5-dose vial. The baseline is complete, and the study started implementation mid-December 2020 and will continue for 1 year. We are implementing 3 arms in the study (5-dose vial and trainings, 10-dose vial and trainings, and control group) and will measure the impact on immunization coverage pre and post implementation. The findings from this study will be highly relevant for Ethiopia and other countries considering changing to a 5-dose measles vial.

comment.narrative: The measles 5 dose study reached 6 months of RCT implementation mid-June 2021. Reports are available, and a full mid-term assessment of where the team is in terms of the field activities is being planned for after the General Election.

title.narrative: CDC Foundation
Complete of implementation period (runs in total for 16 months), and reporting on status. Carry out endline survey.

target.value: Missed opportunities for vaccination due to healthcare worker reluctance to open a multi-dose vial is well described in the literature. CDC has been working with Ethiopia FMoH and immunization partners to design and implement a randomized control study to document and measure the impact of reduce Measles vial size from 10 dose/vial to 5 dose/vial. IRB approval has already been optained and baseline data collection is planned to begin Q4 2019. We propose to continue to implement the 3 arms of the study (5-dose vial and trainings, 10-dose vial and trainings, and control group) and measure the impact on immunization coverage during 2020-2021. The funds identified are the anticipated needs to complete the full implementation, which will begin Q2 2020 with funds already recieved under the last TCA cycle. The findings from this study will be highly relevant to other countries considering the cost and benefit of changing to a 5-dose measles vial.

comment.narrative: 10 months of implementation are now complete and are on track to carry out the remaining implementation. The endline survey remains scheduled as planned in March-April 2022 and current survey details are being discussed.

target.value: Missed opportunities for vaccination due to healthcare worker reluctance to open a multi-dose vial is well described in the literature. CDC has been working with Ethiopia FMoH and immunization partners to design and implement a randomized control study to document and measure the impact of reduce Measles vial size from 10 dose/vial to 5 dose/vial. IRB approval has already been optained and baseline data collection is planned to begin Q4 2019. We propose to continue to implement the 3 arms of the study (5-dose vial and trainings, 10-dose vial and trainings, and control group) and measure the impact on immunization coverage during 2020-2021. The funds identified are the anticipated needs to complete the full implementation, which will begin Q2 2020 with funds already recieved under the last TCA cycle. The findings from this study will be highly relevant to other countries considering the cost and benefit of changing to a 5-dose measles vial.

comment.narrative: 6 months of implementation is now complete, and on track to carry out the remaining implementation. The endline survey will be carried out in March-April 2022 given where the team is with the current stage of the implementation of the measles 5 dose study.

target.value: Missed opportunities for vaccination due to healthcare worker reluctance to open a multi-dose vial is well described in the literature. CDC has been working with Ethiopia FMoH and immunization partners to design and implement a randomized control study to document and measure the impact of reduce Measles vial size from 10 dose/vial to 5 dose/vial. IRB approval has already been optained and baseline data collection is planned to begin Q4 2019. We propose to continue to implement the 3 arms of the study (5-dose vial and trainings, 10-dose vial and trainings, and control group) and measure the impact on immunization coverage during 2020-2021. The funds identified are the anticipated needs to complete the full implementation, which will begin Q2 2020 with funds already recieved under the last TCA cycle. The findings from this study will be highly relevant to other countries considering the cost and benefit of changing to a 5-dose measles vial.

comment.narrative: 6 months of implementation is now complete, and on track to carry out the remaining implementation. The endline survey will be carried out in March-April 2022 given where the team is with the current stage of the implementation of the measles 5 dose study.

title.narrative: Complete a further 6 months of the implementation phase initiated in selected zones

The funds identified are the anticipated needs to complete the full implementation, which will begin Q2 2020 with funds already recieved under the last TCA cycle. title.narrative: CDC Foundation : Programme Implementation/Coverage & Equity

Funding received, a) IRB protocol developed and submitted for review; b-e) reference materials gathered, best practices materials gathered from other countries, and locally to strengthen implementation; f) continue work started last TCA cycle

target.value: In support the introduction of MCV2 in Ethiopia in early 2019, technical support subnationally in one large Region (specificially Oromia Region), including a) operations research to identify and mitigate barriers to uptake of MCV2 and second year of life (2YL) services; b) support around recording/reporting of vaccines doses delivered in 2YL; c) roll-out of training materials for MCV2, with emphasis on use of MCV2 as an opportunity to catch-up children on measles vaccinations that were missed during the first year of life; d) communications messaging to increase awareness and demand for MCV2; e) capacity building for data quality assurance, analysis and triangulation for MCV1 & MCV2 at the local level (i.e. health facility level within Oromia); f) experience sharnig activities on 2YL programs

comment.narrative: IRB protocol was developed and approved by the scientific and ethical review committee of the Oromia Regional Health Bureau. Field work is completed, analysis and write up are now ongoing.

title.narrative: a) Final report on study findings and dissemination through various fourms; b, c, e) Materials pilot tested and status reported; d) recommendations on approaches aimed at increasing awareness and demand for MCV2, with focus subnationally in Oromia Region

target.value: In support the introduction of MCV2 in Ethiopia in early 2019, technical support subnationally in one large Region (specificially Oromia Region), including a) operations research to identify and mitigate barriers to uptake of MCV2 and second year of life (2YL) services; b) support around recording/reporting of vaccines doses delivered in 2YL; c) roll-out of training materials for MCV2, with emphasis on use of MCV2 as an opportunity to catch-up children on measles vaccinations that were missed during the first year of life; d) communications messaging to increase awareness and demand for MCV2; e) capacity building for data quality assurance, analysis and triangulation for MCV1 & MCV2 at the local level (i.e. health facility level within Oromia); f) experience sharnig activities on 2YL programs

comment.narrative: The MCV2 barriers assessment has completed all the field work and the study findings are currently being compiled into a final report. There are two sections to the work that are currently undergoing analysis: a) the quantitative survey across 18 districts of healthcare workers, caregivers and EPI focal persons in the Region (in total >1,600 individuals were interviewed), and b) a series of detailed qualitative focus group discussions (>80), and in-depth interviews (> 40) with healthcare workers, caregivers, EPI focals and community leaders across 10 districts. Both will be combined for one overall comprehensive report on the barriers to MCV2 across the Oromia Region. Increasing the awareness on the demand for MCV2 is complete through radio messaging in the local language across the Region, and also ongoing demand generation activities.

title.narrative: UNICEF : Leadership, management, and coordination (LMC)
Equity or Accessibility assessment performed

target.value: EPI performance review and/or MSD supported and progress documented

comment.narrative: Immunization performance for the EFY 2013 was reviewed at MoH level with the presence of MoH, RHB and zonal level EPI officer, consultants, and other EPI partners. Besides, Amhara, Oromia, SNNP and Sidama regions also reviewed annual performance. Consultants deployed by UNICEF through contribution from GAVI TCA fund in 14 zones and three regional health bureaus supported the review process and documentation of progresses, challenges, and lesson. UNICEF with Government EPI officers and team leads from 14 zones and four targeted regions also reviewed the performance of routine immunization and lessons. UNICEF with WHO prepared routine immunization improvement plan which is endorsed by the MoH. In UNICEF supported zones, the administrative coverage for penta3 and MCV1 increased from 94% in 2018/19 to 100% in20/21 and MCV1 from 89% to 95% and MCV2 from 49% to 77% during similar period. Similarly, the dropout from penta1 to penta3 and penta1 to MCV1 dropped from 6% to % and 11% to 9% respectively. There is improvement in coverage and reduction of dropouts compared with average non-UNICEF targeted Zones.

title.narrative: In-depth assessement of data quality (DQR, DQA, audit) performed

target.value: EPI performance review and/or MSD supported and progress documented

comment.narrative: The activity described here is not in line with the milestone. However, EPI performance review for EFY 2013 will be held by next quarter. UNICEF will provide technical and financial support. The detail progress will be reported in November 2021 when the activity is completed.

title.narrative: UNICEF : Service Delivery
Data Improvement Plan (DIP) implemented

target.value: Immunization service avilability monitored biannually by type of HFs in 14 Zones and at least one advocacy meeting conducted per zone for service expantion

comment.narrative: As per the national health facility standard, all health facilities in Ethiopia are supposed to provide immunization services. However, as per the 2018 service availability and readiness assessment (SARA) only about 81 per cent of health facilities were providing immunization service. Nearly one out of five health facilities were not able to provide immunization service. It is important to monitor the proportion of health facilities providing immunization service and reasons for why some health facilities are not providing services in UNICEF supported zones. Through identifying the reasons context specific support provided to start offering immunization service. In 2021, in UNICEF supported 14 Zones 1024 (25.7%) health centers and 4967 (29%) health posts were identified from master health facility list and checked whether the health facilities reported immunization service at least for more than three months biannually. A total of 93 health facilities (12 in Sidama and 81 in SNNP) are supported to provide immunization service. The monitoring system is initiated by UNICEF deployed consultants embedded in zones/region health offices. The monitoring system is established with regular reporting system through DHIS2 which is simple to monitor health facility service provision status for their respective jurisdiction and can be done and sustained by government programme officers. However, in UNICEF supported two zones of Amhara and two zones of Oromia a total of 224 HCs and 915 health posts are affected by recent security escalation and interrupted services. UNICEF is supporting at regional states to prepare the catchup plans.

title.narrative: Data improvement field activity implemented (review, validation, monitoring, harmonisation, mentorship, workshop, others)

target.value: Identification , mapping, and targeting through REC micro-plan preparation to reach missed/underserved communities in six zones with high number of zero dose children

comment.narrative: GAVI TCA fund through UNICEF has supported 153 woreda health offices and 570 health centers in Sidama, three zones in SNNP and four zones in Oromia region to identify, map, and target underserved villages and prepare micro-plans. A total of 1410 (871 in Oromia region and 539 SNNP) underserved villages were identified and mapped during the micro-planning. The identification and mapping of the underserved villages helped to reach zero dose and under vaccinated children. Immunization service provided in 8594 session (5190 in Oromia and 3378 in SNNP) of which 2799 fixed and 5795 outreaches. A total of 1849 children aged 12 to 23 months were checked for their vaccination status through rapid community survey. The result showed 88, 78 and 36 per cent coverage for penta3, MCV1 and MCV2 respectively. In general, there is considerable gap between administrative and community survey data where administrative data is higher often 100+ for the first dose of penta1 and penta3.

title.narrative: Equity or Accessibility assessment performed

target.value: Identification , mapping, and targeting through REC micro-plan preparation to reach missed/underserved communities in six zones with high number of zero dose children

comment.narrative: Identification of under served communities, mapping and targeting for immunization service is critical to ensure equitable access and use of services. Learning from previous UNICEF supported Zones, Oromia and Amhara regional health bureaus requested UNICEF to expand technical and financial support. However, as support is limited the RHBs opted to shift TAs to new zones where the capacity is relatively low. Accordingly, Oromia and Amhara regional health bureaus shifted UNICEF deployed TAs into four and two new zones respectively. In four Zones of Oromia region (67%) about 526 underserved/risk communities were identified under 301 PHCU catchments and 68 woredas. The identification and mapping were conducted by organizing 12 RED/REC workshops through engaging 518 woreda and health center managers and EPI focal persons for three days. The underserved community was identified based on geographic, topographic, other social characteristics, analyzing service provision modalities and settlements. Besides, immunization coverage pattern, defaulter rate, incidence of measles outbreak in health facility catchments were considered for identification of low performing health facilities and underserved communities. Then the health facilities were prioritized, and the underserved communities were mapped in each health facility catchment. Each health facility target and plan appropriate service delivery modality as per the local context. Accordingly, the number of service delivery points are expanded. In two zones of Amhara, REC micro planning is currently ongoing. Technical support will be provided to PHCUs and woreda to be able follow up and regularly monitor the access and use of services using a package of monitoring tools. Immunization service will be an indicator for community score card. Facility community linkage will be strengthened for sustaining services. The programme trigger additional health post construction will be initiated in isolated and remote villages

title.narrative: Master facility list platform implemented

target.value: Immunization service avilability monitored biannually by type of HFs in 14 Zones and at least one advocacy meeting conducted per zone for service expantion

comment.narrative: Immunization service availability from health facilities monitored in UNICEF supported 14 Zones. Health facilities not providing immunization services were reduced from 617 to 440 (29% reduction from March 2020 to March 2021) in 14 UNICEF supported Zones. In total immunization service expanded to 177 additional health facilities with one year. Reasons for not providing immunization service were multiple including, availability of health post and Health center in the same compound so that HC not provided immunization, non-functional refrigerator, shortage of trained human resource, conflict and negligence. Advocacy and performance review meetings have been conducted in seven zones of SNNP and Oromia (50% achievement). UNICEF consultants collected data on immunization service provision status and identified for barriers by woreda. Immunization service status and performance was presented and discussed in the review and advocacy meeting where zonal and woreda health managers are participated One of the key actions following the meeting was to expand immunization service in health facilities where there was no immunization service. UNICEF consultants with zonal and woreda EPI officers provided technical support and monitor service commencement and/or resumption immunization service. The advocacy and performance review meeting has contributed to start immunization service in health facilities that were not providing before. While Zonal advocacy and review meeting will be held in Amhara and Sidama integrating with other COVID-19 vaccine rollout.

title.narrative: Data desk review or triangulation analysis performed (coverage, surveillance, operational, others)

target.value: Coverage survey conducted in at least 70 villages far from health facilities and risk communities in 14 zones to generate evidence on zero dose and under vaccination

comment.narrative: In UNICEF supported zones there are 1024 Health centers and 4967 health posts. During the reporting period, UNICEF deployed consultants supervised 345 (33.7%) health centers and 345 (7%) Health posts in the target zones. The consultants also conducted data quality verification in 266 health posts and monitored 117 immunization sessions at static and outreach sites. Rapid community survey was conducted in 311 villages to check vaccination status among 3420 children aged 12 to 23 months. The data verification findings showed that only 67% reported within acceptable range, while 21% over reported and 12% were under reporting. The overreporting increase for the later doses for penta3, MCV1 and MCV2. The session monitoring results indicated that among the 35 outreach sessions only 30% were supported by community members (HAD) which indicated fatigue of the community platform. Home based registration cards were provided in 77% visited sessions. Regarding key messages, about 82%, 64%, 55% and 54% communicated about when to return or appointment date, possible side effects, keeping the vaccination card and about the vaccine type. The rapid community survey results showed that 95.6%, 89.8%, 80.4% coverage for penta1, penta3 and MCV1 respectively. The dropout rate from penta1 to penta3 and penta1 to MCV1 was 7 and 16.8% respectively.

title.narrative: Routine immunisation coverage survey (national /targeted - various methods) implemented

target.value: Coverage survey conducted in at least 70 villages far from health facilities and risk communities in 14 zones to generate evidence on zero dose and under vaccination

comment.narrative: UNICEF supported 14 Zones with high number of unvaccinated children benefiting 30.4 million (27.8%) of the total population. During the first half of the year 2021 local rapid community surveys were conducted in 75 villages of (107%) achievement. A total of 932 children aged 0 to 23 were surveyed. Home based registration card (HBR) was found only for 63% and 58% of 0 to 11 and 12 to 23 months aged children respectively. Community surveys revealed shortage and unavailability of HBR card in many health facilities particularly in health posts. The rapid community survey coverage among surveyed children for tracer antigens were 96%, 87% and 77% for Penta 1, Penta 3 and MCV1 respectively. Out of 615 children aged 12 to 23 months, about 77% were fully vaccinated, 20% were defaulters and 3% were never vaccinated. Penta1 coverage is high in line with administrative coverage whereas the latter doses were low which indicated considerable proportion of under immunized children. Caregivers were asked why the dropped from vaccination and main responses were lack of information on the date of vaccination, vaccinator absent, computing priorities and fear of multiple injection and adverse events following immunization. Thus, concerted effort is required to address the defaulters. There are villages with and without mobile network coverage. Availability of mobile phone in the household was not assessed. This is important parameter and will include in the immunization status assessment tool. Community health workers are there but only 29% of outreach sessions were supported by volunteer community health workers. There was HBR shortage at national level. The MoH is printing HBR and soon it will be available in health facilities. Local radio is available in many places and contributing for disseminating messages.

title.narrative: John Snow, Inc. : Programme Management - General

Afar and Somali RHBs have a list of woredas with planned review meetings (incl PIRI/MCV2). Technical assistance provided to priority woredas for the preparation of PIRI/MCV2 related review meetings, including coaching/on-job support and guidance documents or templates as needed

target.value: Assist Afar and Somali RHBs in coordination and support regarding prep and follow-up of review meetings and provide technical assistance to select woredas conducting immunization (including PIRI/MCV2) review meetings.

comment.narrative:
Both regions identified woredas that needed follow up and support for improving uptake of MCV2 and support for PIRI. A total of 43 woredas in the two regions (29 in Somali and 14 in Afar) were prioritized by RHB for technical assistance for review meetings.
In Somali region, a regional level review meeting was organized by RHB in July 2021 where most of the PIRI/MCV2 poor-performing woredas attended. JSI provided technical assistance to the RHB and woredas to ensure gaps were understood and clear action points were set. Clear guidance for provision of MCV2 as part of other routine immunization was given to all woredas by RHB. The project also provided technical assistance to zonal level review meetings organized in two zones: Fafan zone (where 14 woredas attended) and Jarar zone (where 8 prioritized woredas attended). For other zones in the region, the project supported zonal level review meetings virtually through advising via phone and discussion with RHBs. For all zones, the analysis on MCV2 uptake and facilities not providing MCV2 was shared for use during their zonal and woreda level review meetings. In Afar region, the support for review meeting was done at woreda level. Technical assistance was provided in person at three woreda-level review meetings, where action points were developed to improve PIRI/MCV2. The RHB also attended the review meetings. For other 11 prioritized woredas, the project provided technical assistance on organizing review meeting remotely. The main issues and agenda discussed during the review meetings included: RI performance status, gaps and challenges of 2021, MCV1 and MCV2 specific performance status of 2020 and 2021 and gaps, and other RMNCH performance status of 2021. During the review meetings, JSI provided technical assistance on identification of data from DHIS2, development of agenda and PPT presentation, as well as follow-on on-job support and coaching based on the gaps identified during the review meeting.

title.narrative: Afar and Somali RHBs monitor capacity building plans and assess status using existing coordination and discussion mechanisms (e.g., technical working group meetings)

target.value: Provide technical assistance to Afar and Somali RHBs in developing and monitoring a capacity building plan for woredas/PHCUs on PIRI/MCV2.

comment.narrative: During the reporting period, JSI supported Afar and Somali RHBs to implement and monitor the capacity building plans they?d developed. The capacity building plan included actions and activities to be carried out in each region to ensure successful rollout of PIRI and scale up of MCV2 within the health system. Based on the plan, technical assistance was provided to the RHBs and the progress of the plan was monitored regularly with the RHB and TWGs. JSI provided technical assistance and on-job training to RHB team on extracting data from DHIS2 and analysis of the performance of each woreda using RED categorization tool, follow up action points, and communication with woredas. Based on data analysis, both regions developed a list of priority woredas for targeted assistance (29 woredas in Somali and 18 woredas in Afar were prioritized due to poor MCV2 performance). In Afar, all hard-to-reach kebeles within the region were identified; this information was used to update the specific areas to be targeted using PIRI resources. For woredas with consistent poor performance on PIRI/MCV2, JSI provided supportive supervision to the woredas (three rounds per region) to identify challenges and provide clear action points to improve the status of the woredas and health facilities. In Somali, SS was provided to 10 WoHO, 18 HC and 30 HPs; in Afar, SS was provided to 10 WoHO, 14 HC, and 10HP. All SS visits were conducted together with RHB staff, as an additional opportunity to build capacity of RHB staff to problem solve and monitor progress of the program. Additionally, JSI provided technical assistance to the RHBs during the rollout of immunization related trainings (IIP, IRT and MLM) using MoH resource from PIRI. MCV2 was included in all PIRI-funded trainings provided in both regions.

title.narrative: Afar and Somali RHBs have PIRI and MCV2 status reviewed and situation analysed and summarized into one report per region.

target.value: Review of PIRI and MCV2 performance status and situation analysis in Afar and Somali regions.

comment.narrative: JSI conducted a rapid situational analysis (SA) on the implementation of PIRI and MCV2 in Afar and Somali regions. The objective of the Rapid SA was to examine the current implementation status of PIRI and MCV2 in Somali and Afar regions to improve understanding of program success, gap or challenge areas, and priority actions needed. The findings provided information to each RHB and the MOH for better planning, implementation, and monitoring of these activities as well as further refining the planned regional level technical assistance from JSI. Findings were presented at national level through a briefing to the EPI team at MOH, as well as during a national level TCA coordination meeting for expanded partners conducted at Adama. At regional level, findings were presented at the regional TWG in each region. The Rapid SA methodology, findings, and recommendations are summarized in the attached report.

title.narrative: Afar and Somali RHBs have mapped partners working on MCV2 and PIRI, and list partners by area of support and geography. Afar and Somali RHBs will organize a partners meeting and/or use existing coordination platforms to share situational analysis findings and develop a coordinated regional plan of action.

target.value: Mapping of partners and harmonization of implementation plans for PIRI/MCV2 in Afar and Somali regions.

comment.narrative: Partner mapping was completed as part of each region?s Rapid Situational Analysis (SA). Overall, there is varied support related to immunization being provided in both regions, but often concentrated in select woredas. At the regional level, coordination for immunization activities is done mainly through technical working group meetings with RHB and active partners. Additional results are included in the Rapid SA Report. After conducting partner mapping, both regions organized a meeting with their respective RHBs and immunization partners to present the Rapid SA findings and to develop an action plan based on the report recommendations. Both Afar and Somali held their meetings as part of the regional TWG in March 2021.

title.narrative: Document on partners mapping by geography and specific areas of support. MOH develops or adapts a simplified tool/checklist used to monitor and follow up implementation as per PIRI protocol and MCV2 rollout.

target.value: Provide a national level technical advisor to support MOH efforts in PIRI equity zones and developing regional states (DRS) with planning, implementation and monitoring of PIRI and MCV2, including strengthening links between MOH and DRS RHBs and developing guidance documents as needed.

comment.narrative: Regions submitted quarterly PIRI performance reports to national level for monitoring. Through its embedded national level advisor, JSI facilitated regular data analysis and monitoring on the progress of PIRI rollout and MCV2 coverage during the implementation period. Data from July 2020-February 2021 showed MCV2 72% and MCV1 87% at national level; 53% MCV2 coverage for Somali; 51% of MCV2 for Afar region. MCV2 data analysis conducted by JSI for FMOH and regions is attached. JSI also provided support to various MOH priority activities in its workplan related to improving MCV2 uptake, PIRI, and routine immunization overall. For example, an MCV2 job aid was developed in English and shared in late 2020, with printing/distribution to select areas provided by USAID Transform HDR Project. Currently, the job aid is being translated to Amharic and Somali languages, pretested for clarity, functionality, and quality, and will be further printed and disseminated to woredas where MCV2 is lagging. The pretesting plan for Amharic/Somali versions is attached. In addition, JSI participated in the integrated supportive supervision (ISS) during the reporting period. The TA visited Somali region?s Harshin and Awbera woredas, using a standard checklist revised to include MCV2 and PIRI related indicators. ISS feedback was provided on-site to health workers at health facility, woreda, and RHB levels; a national level debriefing was conducted for the MOH management team. Lastly, JSI participated in an MCV2 advocacy meeting in Gambella region, integrated with COVID-19 activities. Representatives from RHB MCH department, woreda health offices, religious leaders, other sectors (e.g. education), and partners were present. During the meeting, JSI delivered a presentation on the current status of MCV2 and implementation challenges. IEC materials were shared to participants and action points were developed to conduct catch-up and various social mobilization activities.

title.narrative: MOH convenes partners to review progress to date on PIRI implementation, completion/timeliness of reporting, and other implementation issues. Coordination/support visits conducted to priority RHBs.

target.value: Provide a national level technical advisor to support MOH efforts in PIRI equity zones and developing regional states (DRS) with planning, implementation and monitoring of PIRI and MCV2, including strengthening links between MOH and DRS RHBs and developing guidance documents as needed.

comment.narrative: Through an embedded national advisor, JSI provided full-time support to the EPI with a focus on improving PIRI implementation and strengthening MCV2 uptake. JSI supported the analysis of administrative data (DHIS2) for MCV1/MCV2 and provided feedback to lower levels on key findings. JSI also prepared national EPI program and RMNCH directorate programs review meeting presentations, highlighting key data and issues related to PIRI activities and MCV2 delivery. To address the effects of acute security situations, JSI compiled a list of about 270 conflict and IDP affected woredas and prepared a costed proposal to support vaccination response activities integrated with PIRI. To improve knowledge gaps at health facility level, JSI had prepared an MCV2 job aid. During this reporting period, the job aid was pre-tested and translated to Amharic and Somali languages, and 2000 copies were printed and distributed (600 to Somali region, and 1400 Amharic copies to Afar, Benishangul Gumuz, Amhara, and SNNPR regions). JSI briefed regional EPI focals and immunization partners over Zoom on how to introduce and use the job aid. JSI also began preparatory activities for the development of a national catch up vaccination guide, which is planned to be completed in the subsequent TCA contract. JSI briefed EPI and ensured its inclusion in the MOH?s overall workplan, briefed the national technical working group on rationale and overall activity, established a sub working group, developed an outline, and began discussions on key technical decisions in the guide (e.g. establishing a catch up schedule with upper age limits). JSI also supported partner coordination by participating in the Oct 2021 Gavi TCA coordination meeting.

title.narrative: three Community engagement strategy for high risk communties is implemented in 14 zones in Amhara,SNNPR and oromia

target.value: Enhance community engagement in the UNICEF supported 14 zones of three large regions and Addis Ababa to increase immunization uptake Key activities 1 Develop and implement tailored behavior and social changes strategy for remote rural, urban scattered communities , conflict affected and communities with low socio-economic status and implementation in 14 zones in Amhara Oromia and SNNPR 2. Monitoring of community participation, especially of women, in the planning and monitoring of immunization sessions in the framework of the RED/REC 3. Strengthen SBCC coordination at regional level and in 14 UNICEF targeted zones, among programmes, particularly of EPI and HEP, and partners including women networks and other local CSOs; 4. Support MCV2 , Measles SIA and NVI roll out in communication planning, development/adjustment of communication tools, and monitoring

comment.narrative: During the reporting period, UNICEF ECO has been able to apply Human Centered Design thinking approach (HCD) for the development of tailored demand interventions in Oromia and SNNP regions. A national C4D consultant for tailored demand generation strategies is recruited on 20th Feb 2021 until 19 November 2021. The consultant has been trained and mentored on application Human Centered Design thinking approach with technical support of The Nucleus, an agency contracted by EASRO/HQ. By the reporting period, rapid inquiries have been conducted with participation of Regional Health Bureau, health workers, caregivers and community members. Under TCA 2021, it is already planned to proceed with ideation, prototyping, implementation, scale up and monitoring and evaluation for urban-poor communities in Oromia and rural-poor communities in SNNP which have the high number of zero-dosed and under-immunized children.

title.narrative: Plan to overcome vaccine demand-related barriers in high risk communities developed

target.value: Capacity building of EPI/health promotion officers from prioritized zones of Amhara, Oromia and SNNP on Human Centered Design Thinking approach for contextualized immunization demand generation

comment.narrative: ?Introduction to Human Centered Designed thinking approach; Creating demand for health and immunization services? which is one and half hour virtual session was conducted on 5th April 2021. About (50) participants who are representatives from Ministry of Health, Communication and Community Engagement Technical Working Group members, and EPI/C4D focal from regional offices were participated in this session. It was facilitated by The Nucleus, contracted by UNICEF EASRO/HQ. Following the orientation session, Master Classes on HCD which is a 3-day (3 hours per day) TOT training was conducted on 6-8 April 2021. About (30) participants from the regional offices and country office attended the training including interactive exercises. Training at the regional level is in the planning process.

target.value: Prototyping of demand generation intervention by using human centered design thinking approach in peri-urban communities of Oromia which has highest number of zero-dosed children

comment.narrative: Before the HCD TOT training, rapid inquiry by utilizing HCD approach was conducted with participation on the Oromia Regional Health Bureau, woreda-level health workers, caregivers and community leaders. Key barriers to routine immunization services has been identified. In the second half of 2021, it is planned to conduct ideation session and prototyping of prioritized intervention which is tailored for the peri-urban communities in Oromia region.

target.value: Capacity building of EPI/health promotion officers from prioritized zones of Amhara, Oromia and SNNP on Human Centered Design Thinking approach for contextualized immunization demand generation

comment.narrative: National-level TOT training and orientation session on application of HCD has been conducted in April 2021 with participation of national and sub-national level EPI/C4D focal. About 46 participants participated in the orientation session and about 33 participants from the Ministry of Health, Regional Health Bureau, and partners participated in the 3-day training. Participants are from different regions across the country. Partner agency, Emory University, also participated in the training for application of MCH service demand in Beninshangul-Gumuz and Afar regions as well. Training package on application of HCD for immunization demand has been developed for subnational EPI officers/health promotion officers. There is an ongoing discussion with RHB/FO on the training dates which are tentatively planned in Dec 2021 and Jan 2022.

title.narrative: Implementation of C4I activities at the community level in the prioritized zones are monitored.

target.value: Monitoring on the implementation of community engagement activities in prioritized zones of Amhara, SNNP and Oromia especially on the participation of women, in the planning and monitoring of immunization sessions in the framework of the RED/REC

comment.narrative: Starting from early March 2021, 2 C4D Officers-UNV in Amhara Region, 2 in SNNP/Sidama regions and 2 in Oromia Region have been appointed and supporting on the monitoring of community engagement activities in an integrated manner. During September-November 2021, C4D-UNV conducted at least two field visits per region for integrated supportive supervision to the health centers and communities in Oromia, SNNP/Sidama and Amhara regions. In Amhara, a rapid assessment was conducted and it was higlighted SBC interventions on immunization and outbreak response such as measles need to be strenthen particularly among the IDP communities. UNICEF is currently supporting EPI team of MOH on development of simplified monitoring templated with standardized key indicators which will also be part of the national demand promotion on routine immunization plan of action.

title.narrative: UNICEF : Supply chain
EVMA performed

target.value: Conducted EVMA self-assessment in 85% of EPSA centre and hubs and 80% of districts at the 14 UNICEF supported zones, EVM Improvement plan developed; and attain EVM indicator for temperature (E2) at least 80% in 85% of the targets once in a year.

comment.narrative: As part of local capacity improvement on effective cold chain and vaccine management, woreda and health center conducted effective vaccine management self-assessment. Bases on self-assessment findings woreda and health facility vaccine and cold chain focal points are encouraged to prepare improvement plans and monitor progress monthly. In UNICEF assisted zones about 103(81%) of woredas and 524 (77%) of health centers were supported to conduct EVM self-assessment using 24 and 25 item checklists. Among the woredas conducted self- assessment 61% of woredas and 67.4% of health centers scored 80% and above. During the reporting period, no stock out and overstock of antigens were reported from the woredas and health facilities that conducted self-assessment. UNICEF staff also supported six EPSA hubs on the implementation of EVMA improvement plan.

target.value: Conducted EVMA self-assessment in 85% of EPSA centre and hubs and 80% of districts at the 14 UNICEF supported zones, EVM Improvement plan developed; and attain EVM indicator for temperature (E2) at least 80% in 85% of the targets once in a year.

comment.narrative: Cold chain and vaccine management focal persons? self-assessment on effective vaccine management (EVM) was demonstrated to improve the effective vaccine and cold chain management in pharmaceutical supply agency (PSA) hubs. The self-assessment initiative was also rolled out to woreda health office cold rooms and health centers. The self-assessment initiative was implemented in 89 woredas in UNICEF supported Zones through support from UNICEF ECO and technical assistance. Woreda and health facilities vaccine management focal persons were provided tools with 24 to 25 item questions and orientations to conduct EVM self-assessment. Through follow-up and supervision woreda cold chain store and health center effective vaccine management score improved from 51% (baseline) to 63% for woredas and HC, 52% to 67% for health centers within four to six months. Such initiative is important on the maintain the potency of vaccines at service delivery level and will continue to reach at least 80% standard. The the baseline for self-assessment was the 2019 national EVMA assessment at woreda and service delivery level.

title.narrative: Data desk review or triangulation analysis performed (coverage, surveillance, operational, others)

target.value: Triangulatation conducted on vaccine stock and performance, administrataive data validated and feedback provided quarterly in 80% of woredas in 14 UNICEF supported zones in Amhara, Oromia and SNNP Regions.

comment.narrative: Data triangulation and taking remedial action is critical in areas where inflated administrative coverage data are reported. Immunization data from small scale surveys and administrative data was reviewed from facility catchment. Feedbacks from both data sources provided for respective health managers. In most areas administrative coverage is higher than survey data. However, the discrepancy is not as high as in large scale surveys. With support from UNICEF TAs small scale local surveys are conducted to verify dropouts and zero-dose children in specific health capacity catchment where 100+ coverage is reported. During the last six months, data quality verification was conducted in 106 health facilities particularly at health post level in 78 woredas. The verification was made by dividing recounted from source document by reported number. Those reported figure from 90 to 110% are considered as normal. While those reported below 90% considered as over reporting and greater than 110% were considered as under reporting. About 67% health posts reported within acceptable range while about one third over or under reported. Many health posts tend to over report and over reporting increases for later doses such as MCV1 and MCV2 this is almost similar across the health facilities. For example, about 30(29%) and 11 (10%) health posts had over and under reported respectively. Similarly, for MCV2 46(43%) and 10(9%) health posts over and under reported respectively. The reason for over and under reporting might be due to lack of source document at health posts and to align with plans. Feedbacks are provided for respective health facilities and health managers. Data triangulation with vaccine issued is undergoing through UNICEF support in collaboration with EPSA.

target.value: Triangulatation conducted on vaccine stock and performance, administrataive data validated and feedback provided quarterly in 80% of woredas in 14 UNICEF supported zones in Amhara, Oromia and SNNP Regions.

comment.narrative: Data triangulation for vaccine distributed and doses given was conducted by desk review through UNICEF support. Four years data (Ethiopian budget year 2009, 2010, 2011 and 2012) doses given from HMIS and doses distributed from LMIS was analyzed. Besides survey data mDHS data was analyzed for the corresponding Ethiopia budget year. The analysis was made for three antigens (Pentavalent, PCV and Rota vaccines). The analysis was conducted for 828 woreda health offices for HMIS and LMIS data. Almost in all regions, HMIS data reported overage compared to LMIS where the reverse was supposed to be true. Among regions Tigray and Benishangul Gumez had relatively better data consistency while Oromia data was the most inconsistent. When mini Demographic and health data was equated with LMIS and HMIS, the DHS data showed the lowest across the analyzed years. This means the number of estimated doses given are lower than the number of doses distributed during matching year which is more likely to happen. Few woredas data was within acceptable range between distributed doses and reported through DHIS2. The findings of data triangulation with presented to PSA and EPI managers at national and sub-national level. Actions was drawn to improve data quality particularly DHIS2 reporting. UNICEF is reporting monthly vaccine stock status (at national and sub national level) improving the data visibility and reporting trends for ESARO

title.narrative: CCE inventory performed/updated

target.value: CCE inventory data regularlly updated and rehabilitation plan developed/implemented for 85% of the national & subnational (EPSA centre & hubs) and 80% districts at 14 Unicef supported zones in three regions, quarterly. (Comment: Can make it clear and the CCEI is done recently by MoH and what is the importance of it)[Response:1. Review CCEOP-ODP implementation /follow up the installation /commissioning and update the CCEI 2. Rehabilitation ? follow up new CCE deployment and maintenance of the existing equipment progress ]

comment.narrative: EPHI through UNICEF and National Logistic Technical Working Group (NLTWG) conducted cold chain inventory in 2019/2020. The draft report was submitted to MoH. The NLTWG reviewed and provided comments on the missed data elements, such as equipment age, model, miss match between model and manufacturer, equipment types etc. The draft report and raw data is now available and used to update the cMYP and used for CCEOP proposals and deployment plan. EPHI is expected to submit the updated report after addressing comments. While the national level inventory data provides overall cold chain status for the country, it has little importance for local level decision making. Local (woreda) level periodic inventory and listing provides information on cold chain status such as functionality to take timely actions. UNICEF consultants with woreda health office and zonal health EPI and cold chain technician conducted simple inventory mainly functionality of refrigerators and types in UNICEF supported zones. Non-functional refrigerators were identified and listed by woreda. Accordingly, the non-functional refrigerators were identified and listed for maintenance purpose. For example, Amhara Regional Health Bureau with technical and financial support from UNICEF and CHAI, trained about 126 woreda and health facility cold chain technicians on cold chain maintenance. As part of the practical training, four Zones organized refrigerator maintenance campaign and maintained 192 non-functional refrigerators which helped to reduce session interruption and improved access to vaccination service. The CCI data is now uploaded in the web based data base.. Once the content of the data is reviewed and endorsed by the NLTWG, access will be provided for the respective regions (including for those UNICEF supported regions and zones). The final and official report is expected from EPHI with in the coming days and it will be shared for all stakeholders.

target.value: CCE inventory data regularlly updated and rehabilitation plan developed/implemented for 85% of the national & subnational (EPSA centre & hubs) and 80% districts at 14 Unicef supported zones in three regions, quarterly. (Comment: Can make it clear and the CCEI is done recently by MoH and what is the importance of it)[Response:1. Review CCEOP-ODP implementation /follow up the installation /commissioning and update the CCEI 2. Rehabilitation ? follow up new CCE deployment and maintenance of the existing equipment progress ]

comment.narrative: Following the 2019 CCE inventory result, in UNICEF supported 12 zones UNICEF deployed consultants identified functional and non-functional refrigerators prepared maintenance plans. Accordingly, 177 technicians trained user level maintenance and maintained a total of 62 refrigerators as part of practical training. GAVI CCEOP Year 2 and 3 with a total of 2562 refrigerators will be installed by two Local service agents: Vest Frost and Bmedical Company. These suppliers did Central and regional level trainings. UNICEF supported Regional Health Bureaus to submit verified ODPs and currently installation is ongoing. As thus far, Bmedical installed 90 SDDs of 359 allocated equipment?s (25%). Vest Frost installed 170 SDDs of 2203 allocated equipment?s (8%). UNICEF through its field offices and consultants is facilitating the installation of SDDs. As part of the effort to strengthen the cold chain system, UNICEF is supporting the procurement of CCEs through various grant sources. With the COVAX CCEs support, a total of 430 ILRs, 59 freezers, 9 WICRs, 3 combined WICRs/FRs, 10,600 vaccine carriers and 1470 cold boxes are on pipeline. CCE support through the GoJ consisting 18 SDDs, 70ILRs, 50 freezers, 2 combo WICRs/FRs, 1150 vaccine carriers and 150 cold boxes are under procurement process and part of the shipment is on transit. UNICEF CO is also facilitating the procurement of additional CCEs mainly to capacitate the service delivery points with funding source form the world bank, totaled 31mUSD. ODP is developed and the PMT is working to finalize and initiate the procurement process.

title.narrative: CDC Foundation : Programme Management - General
Final report on study findings; Materials pilot tested and status reported; recommendations on approaches aimed at increasing awareness and demand for MCV2

target.value: In support the planned introduction of MCV2 in Ethiopia in 2018, operations research to identify and mitigate barriers to uptake of second year of life (2YL) services (e.g. MCV2), and recording/reporting of vaccines doses delivered in 2YL; development and roll-out of training materials for 2YL, with emphasis on use of MCV2 as an opportunity to catch-up children on vaccinations that were missed during the first year of life; communications messaging to increase awareness and demand for MCV2

comment.narrative: The MCV2 barriers assessment has completed all the field work and the study findings are currently being compiled into a final report. There are two sections to the work that are currently undergoing analysis: a) the quantitative survey across 18 districts of healthcare workers, caregivers and EPI focal persons in the Region (in total >1,600 individuals were interviewed), and b) a series of detailed qualitative focus group discussions (>80), and in-depth interviews (> 40) with healthcare workers, caregivers, EPI focals and community leaders across 10 districts. Both will be combined for one overall comprehensive report on the barriers to MCV2 across the Oromia Region. Increasing the awareness on the demand for MCV2 is complete through radio messaging in the local language across the Region, and also ongoing demand generation activities.

title.narrative: Continuation of implementation period, and reporting on status

target.value: Missed opportunities for vaccination due to healthcare worker reluctance to open a multi-dose vial is well described int he literature. CDC has been working with Ethiopia MoH and WHO to design and implement a randomized control study to document and measure the impact of reduce Measles vial size from 10 dose/vial to 5 dose/vial. IRB approval has already been optained and baseline data collection began in Q4 2018. We propose to implement 3 arms of the study (5-dose vial and trainings, 10-dose vial and trainings, and control group) and measure the impact on immunization coverage during 2019-2020. The findings from this study will be highly relevant to other countries considering the cost and benefit of changing to a 5-dose measles vial.

comment.narrative: The measles 5 dose study reached 6 months of Randomized Controlled Trial implementation mid-June 2021. Implementation update reports are available, and a full mid-term assessment of where we are in terms of the field activities is being planned for July 2021.

title.narrative: UNICEF
Two Regional community engagement strategies for high risk communties available for SNNP and Oromia

target.value: Enhance community engagement in the UNICEF supported 14 zones of three large regions and Addis Ababa to increase immunization uptake Key activities 1 Develop and implement tailored behavior and social changes strategy for remote rural, urban scattered communities , conflict affected and communities with low socio-economic status and implementation in 14 zones in Amhara Oromia and SNNPR 2. Monitoring of community participation, especially of women, in the planning and monitoring of immunization sessions in the framework of the RED/REC 3. Strengthen SBCC coordination at regional level and in 14 UNICEF targeted zones, among programmes, particularly of EPI and HEP, and partners including women networks and other local CSOs; 4. Support MCV2 , Measles SIA and NVI roll out in communication planning, development/adjustment of communication tools, and monitoring

comment.narrative: UNICEF ECO has been applying Human Centered Design thinking approach (HCD) for the development of tailored demand interventions in Oromia and SNNP regions. By the reporting period, rapid inquiries have been conducted with participation of Regional Health Bureau, health workers, caregivers and community members in Oromia and SNNP regions. It is planned to proceed further interventions in reaching children in peri-urban community of Oromia and rural-poor community of SNNP by using HCD approach.

title.narrative: WHO : Service Delivery
Support NVI, PIRI, multiantigen catch-up campaigns as requested by FMoH and RHBs

target.value: Provide technical support to implement: ? ? PIRI in the targeted zones ? AVW ? New vaccine introduction (IPV2, COVID-19 vaccine, nOPV2, Yellow fever, MRV and MenAfric A) ? SIA ? Roll out of C-19 and HPV vaccinations in the big four regions

comment.narrative: . Provide technical support to implement: ? ? PIRI in the targeted zones: Technical support planned to conduct PIRI in selected GAVI priority zones was not conducted in 2020 due to COVID-19 Pandemic ? ? AVW: It was not conducted in 2020 because of the same reasons for PIRI, However, the 2021 AVW was supported from the 2020 TCA plan. Defaulter tracing and vaccination going on in 4 of Gavi priority zones, of Amhara and Oromia region which enables the country to reduce number of children missed their scheduled vaccination. ? Roll out of MCV2 to all health facilities: MCV2 is rolled out in more than 90% of the health facilities in the country. Enables the country to increase population immunity and reduce Measles outbreaks We supported during the training and supervision of health care facilities. ? HPV vaccinations: Ethiopia has conducted an integrated HPV vaccination for 2019 and 2020 cohort, in and out of school-girls of age 14 years. The 2019 cohort, second round HPV vaccination could not be conducted due to COVID pandemic. The second dose HPV vaccination of 2019 cohort and first round HPV vaccination of 2020 cohort conducted in January 2021 . WHO recruited 9 technical assistance and supported 4 GAVI priority regions and two city administrations. the deployment of the consultants contributed for success full HPV vaccination. As a result, 81.5% of girls age 14 years of 2019 cohort vaccinated for second dose. and 91.5% of girls age 14 years of 2020 cohort vaccinated for first dose

title.narrative: prepare concept notes, proposals and workplan, assess readiness and monitor implementation and post implementation of the exercises

target.value: Provide technical support to implement: ? ? PIRI in the targeted zones ? AVW ? New vaccine introduction (IPV2, COVID-19 vaccine, nOPV2, Yellow fever, MRV and MenAfric A) ? SIA ? Roll out of C-19 and HPV vaccinations in the big four regions

comment.narrative: WHO has provided technical support which includes supportive supervision and monitoring of the implementation of PIRI activities in the 8 GAVI priority zones of 4 big regions (Amhara,SNNPR,Oromia and Tigray regions).IPV2 switch Concept note prepared and shared with immunization partners. Yellow fever risk assessment survey preparation continued with help of Global EYE secretariat. Measles follow up SIA proposal submitted and approved by GAVI IRC . The country is continuing preparation for November 2021 HPV vaccination and budget provided to Amhara region 2021 AVW

title.narrative: >80% Health facilities (health posts) in the targeted zones and urban slums developed session plans and vaccine requirements and monitor the conduct of sessions (Micro-planning)

target.value: 1.Support training of health workers on the MLM, Combined RED/IIP focusing on (2YL) to new 8 priority zones in four big regions (Tigray, Amhara, Oromia, and SNNPR) and health workers health workers from Health facilities with underserved catchment areas in Addis Ababa and Diredawa City Administrations (urban inequalities)

comment.narrative: West Showa and ARSI zones of Oromia conducted IIP training for 207 health workers with the aim to improve the skill and knowledge of immunization officers, to build their capacity and enable them to provide quality immunization services. South Gondar and AWI zones of Amhara region have completed their preparation to conduct RED and IIP training for health. The remaining two zones of SNNPR and one zone of Tigray regions developed plan and submitted to WHO but because of the delay in the releasing of 2021 GAVI TCA funds implementation IIP training in these 3 zones will not be conducted in the reporting period. The trainings will be conducted when the funds used for staffs recovered from the 2121 GAVI TCA.
